title: Google Unveils Enhanced Find My Device Network, Crowdsourced Tracking for Android & Accessories

Google Unveils Enhanced Find My Device Network in the US and Canada

In a recent announcement, Google revealed the launch of its upgraded Find My Device network in the United States and Canada. This new feature is designed to help Android users locate their misplaced devices and everyday items using a crowdsourced network of more than a billion Android devices. The rollout to other regions is expected to follow soon.

The Find My Device network operates similarly to Apple's Find My network and supports devices running Android 9 and above. This feature allows users to track their Android phones and tablets, even when offline, by ringing them or viewing their location on a map. Google's previous Find My Device service required the lost phone to be connected to the internet to be traceable. The updated network will enable Pixel 8 and 8 Pro users to find their devices even when powered off or if the battery is dead.

From May onwards, Android users can also keep track of everyday items such as keys or wallets. Google is integrating Bluetooth tracker tags from Chipolo and Pebblebee into the Find My Device app. These tags are specifically designed for the Find My Device network, ensuring compatibility with unknown tracker alerts across Android and iOS devices, protecting users from unwanted tracking. Users can anticipate compatible tags from Motorola, Jio, and Eufy later this year.

This development comes after Apple and Google declared last year their collaboration on an industry-wide initiative to notify users of unwanted tracking from Bluetooth devices. Additionally, the new Find My Device network is now compatible with Nest smart home gadgets, displaying the proximity of lost devices to users' home Nest devices.

Erik Kay, Google's VP of Engineering, emphasized the security and privacy of the Find My Device network in a blog post. He stated that multi-layered protections are built into the network to ensure user safety and privacy, maintaining control over devices connected to the network. This includes end-to-end encryption of location data and aggregated device location reporting, a first-of-its-kind safety feature that offers extra protection against unwanted tracking back to a home or private location.

title: Hijacked Facebook Pages Push Fake AI Services for Data Theft: Midjourney AI Scam Uncovered
post_content:
Artificial Intelligence: A New Frontier for Scammers on Facebook

In the ever-evolving world of technology, artificial intelligence (AI) has taken center stage. With tools like ChatGPT and DALL-E gaining popularity worldwide, it's no surprise that scammers are capitalizing on the AI hype to prey on unsuspecting Facebook users. In a recent investigation, cybersecurity firm Bitdefender uncovered a nefarious scheme where scammers lure Facebook users into downloading malicious software disguised as AI services.

Hijacking Facebook Pages and Transforming Them into Fake AI Services

Over the past year, scammers have been hijacking Facebook Pages and rebranding them as legitimate AI services, such as OpenAI's video creation tool Sora and its image creation tool DALL-E. These scammers then run ads on Facebook's ad network, offering early access to experimental AI research and products to those who view the ad. Once users follow the Pages, the scammers post AI-generated content to make the Page appear authentic. They then encourage Page followers to download software, which is, in fact, malware, including Rilide, Vidar, IceRAT, and Nova. These malicious programs steal sensitive data from the user's device.

The Midjourney AI Scam

The most popular Facebook Page discovered in Bitdefender's investigation, Midjourney AI, amassed 1.2 million followers before Facebook removed it in March 2024 for violating its policies. After its removal, other Pages emerged, turning the situation into a game of Whac-a-Mole. Bitdefender reported that the latest scam page impersonating Midjourney had garnered 637,000 followers as of March 26, 2024.

Red Flags and Safety Measures

When users are prompted to download software, there are several red flags. Bitdefender noted that users were given Google Drive or Dropbox links, which should raise suspicions. Additionally, a quick inspection of the Pages would reveal that they are not directly associated with the companies they claim to represent.

Introduction

Have you ever wondered how the prompts you use when interacting with large language models (LLMs) can affect the responses you receive? A team of researchers from the USC Information Sciences Institute (ISI) decided to explore this question, focusing on the reliability of LLM responses to variations in prompts. Their findings, published on the preprint server arXiv, reveal that even subtle changes in prompts can significantly influence LLM predictions.

The Four Categories of Prompt Variations

The researchers examined four categories of prompt variations:

1. Output formats: The team investigated the impact of requesting responses in specific output formats commonly used in data processing, such as lists and CSV files.
2. Perturbations: They analyzed minor modifications to the prompt itself, such as adding extra spaces at the beginning or end, or incorporating polite phrases like "Thank you" or "Howdy!".
3. Jailbreaks: These are techniques used to bypass content filters when dealing with sensitive topics. The researchers explored the use of jailbreaks, asking the LLM to answer as if it was assuming a certain role or character.
4. Incentives: Inspired by the idea that offering a tip could yield better responses, they tested different amounts of tips for "a perfect response."

The researchers tested the prompt variations across 11 benchmark text classification tasks, which typically involve categorizing or assigning labels to text data based on their content or meaning. Title: Enhancing the Autonomy of Climbing Robots: A SLAM-based Approach

Climbing robots have the potential to revolutionize various industries, from maintenance and inspection of high-altitude structures to parcel delivery in hard-to-reach areas. To effectively perform these tasks, these robots must accurately sense and map their surroundings while maintaining precise knowledge of their location. Researchers from Guangdong University of Technology have recently proposed a novel method to improve a bipedal climbing robot's ability to estimate its state and map its environment, specifically when navigating truss structures.

A truss is a triangular system composed of interconnected straight elements, which can be found in bridges, roofs, or other man-made structures. The researchers' proposed method, introduced in Robotics and Autonomous Systems, employs a simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) algorithm tailored to a bipedal climbing robot (BiCR).

Biped Climbing Robot (BiCR)

The BiCR, developed by the Biomimetic and Intelligent Robotics Lab, is an electromechanical system akin to a moving manipulator, capable of moving via grippers at both ends and rotating with multiple joints. This robot can be utilized for installation, maintenance, and inspection in high-altitude and hazardous environments, such as construction site scaffolding and power towers.

SLAM for BiCR

The primary objective of the study was to enable a bipedal climbing robot to autonomously localize itself and create a map of its surroundings while navigating truss structures. The researchers developed BiCR-SLAM, a SLAM-based system specifically for the BiCR robot, which uses information about the robot's configuration, a LiDAR sensing system, and visual data collected by cameras to localize the robot and map the truss it is climbing.

BiCR-SLAM consists of four components: encoder dead reckoning, LiDAR odometry estimation, pole landmark mapping, and a global optimization technique. The global optimization proposes a multi-source fusion factor graph to jointly optimize the robot localization and pole landmarks.

Title: Essential Linux Commands: A Comprehensive Guide for Troubleshooting and System Management

Introduction

Linux is a powerful operating system, and with great power comes great responsibility—and a vast array of commands at your fingertips. As a Linux user, you might not use these commands daily. However, having a solid understanding of these tools, which are built into most Linux distributions, will help you troubleshoot issues and manage your system more effectively. This guide will introduce you to five essential Linux commands that every user should know, including top, df, ps, free, and lsblk.

1. top

The top command provides real-time information about Linux processes. This command is particularly useful when an application or process is misbehaving, and you need to identify the problematic process. The output includes the following columns:

 PID: Process ID
 USER: The owner of the listed process
 PR: The process priority
 NI: The nice value of the process (nice determines the process' priority)
 VIRT: The amount of virtual memory the process is using
 RES: The amount of resident memory the process is using
 SHR: The amount of shared memory the process is using
 S: The status of the process (such as D - uninterruptible sleep, R - running, S - sleeping, T - stopped, and Z - zombie)
 %CPU: The share of CPU time the process is using (since the last update)
 %MEM: The share of physical memory the process is using
 TIME+: The total CPU time the process is using (in hundredths of a second)
 COMMAND: The command associated with the process

You can customize the information displayed or use the top command in conjunction with the kill command to end runaway processes. To learn more about top, consult its manual by typing man top in the terminal.

2. df

The df command displays information about your local storage usage. The output includes a list of columns broken down into Filesystem, Size, Used, Avail, Use%, and Mounted on. Ola, currently valued at $7.3 billion, has decided to pull the plug on its international ride-hailing operations in the U.K., Australia, and New Zealand. Ola's withdrawal from international markets aims to strengthen its position in the Indian market further. Ola's domestic rival, Uber, has recently claimed a higher market share in the South Asian market. Uber chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, stated that the company is dedicated to sustainability and mobility, expanding into new categories while focusing on its core ride-sharing business. Meanwhile, Ola has been exploring different avenues, such as food delivery and electric vehicles.

Despite Ola and Uber's competitive landscape in India, the two companies have not been able to agree on merging their businesses. However, the pandemic has forced both firms to slow down their domestic expansion and focus on improving their unit economics

post_title: Novel robust-optimal controllers based on fuzzy descriptor system
title: Revolutionizing Nonlinear Control: Optimal & Robust-Optimal Controllers for T-S Fuzzy Descriptor Systems
post_content:
Title: Revolutionizing Nonlinear Control with Optimal and Robust-Optimal Controllers

Nonlinear systems are ubiquitous, appearing in various fields, from robotics to economics. However, their inherent complexity makes mathematical modeling and control challenging. To tackle this issue, the Takagi–Sugeno (T–S) fuzzy system has emerged as a powerful tool, approximating nonlinear systems as multiple linear systems using fuzzy logic. In recent years, the fuzzy descriptor system (FDS), an enhanced version of the T–S fuzzy system, has gained traction by combining fuzzy logic with space-state representation.

Despite extensive research, optimal control strategies for T–S FDSs remain largely unexplored, with robust control methods introducing additional complexity and optimization challenges. To address these limitations, a team of researchers led by Associate Professor Ngoc-Tam Bui from Shibaura Institute of Technology and including Thi-Van-Anh Nguyen, Quy-Thinh Dao, and Duc-Binh Pham from Hanoi University of Science and Technology developed novel optimal and robust-optimal controllers based on the T–S fuzzy descriptor model.

The researchers built their controllers on the Lyapunov stability theory, transforming the stability conditions into Linear Matrix Inequalities (LMI) for practical application. This transformation enabled the creation of three distinct controllers: a stability controller, an optimal controller, and a robust-optimal controller.

The stability controller, employing Parallel Distributed Compensator (PDC), effectively managed deviations in the system. The optimal controller minimized a cost function to achieve optimal control, and the robust-optimal controller combined the benefits of both stability and optimal control.

Title: Soaring Towards Infinite Flight: Drones That Charge from Power Lines

Drones have revolutionized various industries, from filmmaking to search-and-rescue missions. However, their limited battery life has always been a significant obstacle. Researchers at the University of Southern Denmark have been tackling this issue, and their recent breakthrough promises an exciting future for drone technology. They've developed a drone that can inspect and charge from power lines, extending its flight time significantly.

The researchers modified a Tarot 650 Sport drone, equipping it with an electric quadcopter propulsion system, an autopilot module, and other essential components. The drone's unique feature is its gripper system, designed to latch onto power lines and recharge the device's battery.

When the drone's battery level drops, the system activates, employing a camera and millimeter-wave radar to locate the closest power line. The drone then maneuvers itself underneath the power line, using its inward-sloping arms to guide the cable into the gripper. An inductive charger draws current from the power line, recharging the battery. Once fully charged, the gripper releases the power line, and the drone resumes its flight.

Initially, the researchers envisioned drones inspecting power lines as the primary application for this charging system. In 2022, they unveiled a self-charging drone that recharged from power lines, albeit with limitations. This time, they've enhanced the gripper system and demonstrated a practical use case for the technology.

In their paper for the IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation, the team described their achievement as "a first-in-the-world system capable of sustaining operation throughout multiple inspection/charging cycles, powered by energy harvesting from power lines in a real outdoor environment." They successfully tested the drone's ability to stay aloft for over two hours, completing five cycles of power line inspection and recharging.
